806.01 CABLE TELEVISION COMMUNITY PROGRAMMING COORDINATOR.
   (a)   There is hereby established the position of Cable Television Community
Programming Coordinator.
   (b)   The duties of the Coordinator include, but are not limited to,
arranging the programming content of the cable television franchisee’s
community programming access channel(s). Such arrangements shall be made in
tandem with the Olmsted Falls City School District and the Township of Olmsted,
through, at such time as either appointments, their counterpart to this
position and any other appropriate entity. There shall be a conscientious
attempt to achieve an optimum balance and timeliness of programming content
among activities of the Administration, issues before Council, recreation and
senior citizen programs and clubs and organizations in the community.
Initially, a new program, approximately thirty minutes in duration, shall be
arranged each month throughout the year, consisting of two or three segments,
followed by a listing of upcoming events, activities and announcements in the
community.
   (c)   The Coordinator shall serve at the pleasure of the Mayor and a
majority of Council and under the technical supervision of the cable television
franchisee and the general supervision of the Olmsted Falls Cable Television
Advisory Board, as provided for by Section 29 of Ordinance 77-79, if
constituted; otherwise, under the supervision of the Community Development
Committee of Council.
   (d)   There shall be no compensation for the Coordinator.
(Ord. 67-84. Passed 5-14-84.)
806.02 REGULATION OF BASIC CABLE TELEVISION RATES.
   The City hereby adopts the rate regulation rules promulgated by the FCC
pursuant to the Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of
1992 (“1992 Cable Act”), 47 C.F.R., Part 76, Subpart N. The determination of
the lawfulness of any cable television rate within the City’s jurisdiction will
be made pursuant to these FCC rules or any successor FCC regulations. All terms
used herein have the same meaning and application as in the FCC’s cable rate
regulation rules. (Ord. 27-94. Passed 2-22-94.)
806.03 ESTABLISHMENT AND DUTIES OF CABLE REGULATORY STAFF.
   (a)   A cable regulatory staff ("the Staff") for the City will be organized
by the Mayor with the assistance, as desired, of the Cuyahoga County Mayors and
Managers Association, in order to administer the regulation of basic cable
service and equipment rates pursuant to FCC's cable rate regulations and the
1992 Cable Act, with the aid of counsel and other consultants as may be needed.
The Council may at any time delegate additional duties to the Staff.
   (b)   In all instances involving the determination of the lawfulness of a
cable television service rate or rates, the Staff will present to the Council a
recommended decision based on the record. The Council may adopt, amend or
remand for further review a recommended decision of the Staff. The Council may
also direct the Staff at any time to investigate issues pertaining to cable
rate regulation and provide a recommended decision. Any adoption by the Council
of any recommended decision by the Staff regarding the lawfulness of a cable
television service rate or rates shall be considered a final decision. The
Staff shall communicate the results of final decisions to the affected cable
operators in writing.
(Ord. 27-94. Passed 2-22-94.)
806.04 COMPUTATION OF TIME.
   This section only applies to time periods that need to be computed for
participation in cable rate regulation proceedings administered by the Staff or
the Council.
   (a)   The term "day" shall apply to all days, regardless of holidays.
   (b)   The term "business day" means all days which are not "holidays."
   (c)   If the date for any event specified in these rules falls on a holiday,
the relevant date will be the next business day.
   (d)   The term "holiday" means Saturday, Sunday, officially recognized legal
holidays and any other day on which the Staff offices are not open. For
example, a regularly scheduled Staff business day may become a "holiday" if its
offices are closed for all or part of regular working hours due to adverse
weather or emergency conditions.
   (e)   The first day to be counted in any period of time is the day after the
event which initiates the period. For example, if comments are to be filed
within five days of a public notice issued on November 12, the deadline for
filing the comments would by November 17.
      (Ord. 27-94. Passed 2-22-94.)
806.05 EFFECTIVE DATE OF RATE REGULATION FOR BASIC SERVICE AND EQUIPMENT.
   Pursuant to 47 C.F.R. 76.910(e)(2) and 76.922, the initial date of
regulation for the basic service tier shall be the date on which local notice
is given to the cable operator that the provision of the basic service tier is
subject to rate regulation. This local notice will be in the form of a letter
sent by the Staff to the cable operator.
(Ord. 27-94. Passed 2-22-94.)
806.06 INITIATION OF REVIEW OF BASIC CABLE SERVICE AND EQUIPMENT RATES.
   Pursuant to 47 C.F.R. 76.930(a), a cable operator shall file its schedule of
rates for the basic service tier and associated equipment with the Staff within
thirty days of receiving written notification from the Staff that the City has
been certified by the FCC to regulate rates for the basic service tier. To
comply with this provision, a cable operator must file a Form 393 regarding
rates that were charged since September 1, 1993, or one year prior to the
commencement of the City's rate regulation, whichever is the shorter period,
and a second Form 393 regarding any proposed rate increases.
(Ord. 27-94. Passed 2-22-94.)
806.07 PARTICIPATION OF INTERESTED PARTIES.
   (a)   For purposes of this chapter, "public notice" shall mean publication
in a newspaper of general circulation as described in Ohio R.C. 7.12.
   (b)   Pursuant to 47 C.F.R. 76.935, the Staff shall, within a reasonable
time, but in any case within the twenty-one days after receiving the cable
operator's Form 393 and any related material, issue a public notice stating
that it has received this information.
   (c)   The notice will provide the address of the City or Staff office where
the operator's Form 393 and any related material will be available for public
viewing within specified times. The notice will also provide the address and
telephone number of the cable operator. The cable operator is required to
provide interested parties, upon request, with copies of the Form 393 and any
related materials filed with the Staff.
   (d)   After the Staff issues the public notice described in paragraphs (a)
through (c) of this section, interested parties will have five business days to
file written comments with the Staff. There is no prescribed format for these
comments.
(Ord. 27-94. Passed 2-22-94.)
806.08 STAFF AND COUNCIL REVIEW OF BASIC CABLE RATES AND EQUIPMENT COSTS.
   (a)   Pursuant to 47 C.F.R. 76.933(a), after a cable operator has submitted
for review its existing or past rates for the basic service tier and associated
equipment costs, or a proposed increase in these rates (including increases in
the baseline channel change that results from reductions in the number of
channels in a tier), the existing rates will remain in effect or the proposed
rates will become effective after thirty days from the date of submission,
provided, however, that the Staff may toll this thirty-day deadline for an
additional time by issuing a brief written order as described in subsection (b)
hereof within thirty days of the rate submission explaining that it needs
additional time to review the rates.
   (b)   Pursuant to 47 C.F.R. 76.933(b), if the Staff is unable to determine,
based upon the material submitted by the cable operator, that the past,
existing or proposed rates are within the FCC's permitted basic service tier
charge or actual cost of equipment as defined in 47 C.F.R. 76.922 and 76.923,
or if a cable operator has submitted a cost-of-service showing pursuant to 47
C.F.R. 76.937(c) and 76.924, seeking to justify a rate above the FCC's basic
service tier charge as defined in 47 C.F.R. 76.922 and 76.923, then the Staff
may toll the thirty-day deadline set forth in subsection (a) hereof to request
and consider additional information or to consider the comments from interested
parties as follows:
      (1)   For an additional ninety days in cases not involving cost-of-
service showings, for a total of 120 days from the filing by the cable operator
of the Form 393; or
      (2)   For an additional 150 days in cases involving cost-of-service
showings, for a total of 180 days from the filing by the cable operator of the
Form 393.
   (c)   Pursuant to 47 C.F.R. 76.933(c), if the Staff has availed itself of
the additional ninety or 150-days permitted under subsection (b) hereof,
whichever is applicable, and has taken no action within these additional time
periods, then the proposed rates will go into effect at the end of the ninety
or 150-day period, whichever is applicable, or, if no new rates have been
proposed, then the existing rates will remain in effect at such times. All
rates allowed into effect under this subsection will remain subject to refunds
if the Staff subsequently issues a written decision disapproving any portion of
such rates, provided, however, that in order to order refunds, the Staff must
have issued a brief written order to the cable operator by the end of the
ninety or 150-day period permitted under subsection (b) hereof, whichever is
applicable, directing the operator to keep an accurate account of all amounts
received by reason of the rate in issue and on whose behalf such amounts were
paid.
   (d)   If the Staff does not seek additional time, the Staff will, within the
thirty-day deadline, submit a recommended decision to the Council about the
reasonableness of the cable operator's rates. If, within the thirty-day period,
the Council does not act upon the Staff's recommended decision, then the
recommended decision will be considered a final decision.
(Ord. 27-94. Passed 2-22-94.)
806.09 ADDITIONAL TIME FOR REVIEW OF RATES FOR BASIC SERVICE AND EQUIPMENT.
   (a)   If the Staff has availed itself of the additional ninety or 150 days
permitted in 47 C.F.R. 76.933(b), whichever is applicable, then the Staff shall
publish a schedule for the issuance of a recommended decision within the
additional time and for the submission of comments by interested parties.
   (b)   Thirty days before the ninetieth day or the 150th day, whichever is
applicable, the Staff shall publish a draft of its recommended decision.
Interested parties will then have five business days to file comments with the
Staff regarding the recommended decision.
   (c)   Upon the expiration of the comment period set forth in subsection (b)
hereof, the record for the cable rate regulation proceeding will close. The
Council will then have an opportunity to review the recommended decision and
any comments or documents filed in the rate proceeding. Nothing in this
subsection prohibits the Council from reviewing the Staff's draft recommended
decision or documents filed with the Staff at any time.
   (d)   If the Council does not act upon the Staff’s recommended decision by
the ninetieth or the 150th day, whichever is applicable, then the recommended
decision will be considered the final decision.
   (e)   Within the ninety or 150-day period, whichever is applicable, the
Council may remand the recommended decision to the Staff for further review
based on the Council's recommendations.
   (f)   If the period for additional review by the Staff extends beyond the
applicable period specified in subsection (a) hereof, then the proposed rates
will go into effect at the end of the ninety or 150-day period, whichever is
applicable, or, if no new rates have been proposed, then the existing rates
will remain in effect at such times. All rates allowed into effect under this
subsection will remain subject to refunds in the event that the Staff
subsequently issues a written decision, pursuant to 47 C.F.R. 76.933(c),
disapproving any portion of such rates.
(Ord. 27-94. Passed 2-22-94.)
806.10 SMALL SYSTEMS.
   (a)   Pursuant to 47 C.F.R. 76.934, the Council may permit a small system,
as defined in 47 C.F.R. 76.901, to certify that the small system's rates for
basic service and associated equipment comply with 47 C.F.R. 76.922.
   (b)   A system seeking the certification described in subsection (a) hereof
must file a petition to this effect with the Staff.
   (c)   Within a reasonable time of receiving such a petition, the Staff shall
issue a public notice, as described in Section
806.07, stating that it has received such a petition. The notice will provide
the address of the Staff office where the petition will be available for public
viewing within specified times. The notice will also provide the address and
telephone number of the cable operator. The cable operator is required to
provide interested parties with copies of the petition. In addition, the notice
will also provide a date for the presentation of a recommended decision by the
Staff to the Council and shall set a date by which the Council must act upon
the recommended decision, which shall be at least thirty days after the
submission of the Staff's recommended decision. If the Council takes no action
by the date designated by the Staff, then the recommended decision shall be
considered a final decision.
   (d)   After the Staff issues the public notice described in subsection (c)
hereof, interested parties will have five business days to file written
comments with the Staff. There is no prescribed format for these comments.
(Ord. 27-94. Passed 2-22-94.)
806.11 WRITTEN DECISION.
   Pursuant to 47 C.F.R. 76.936, the Staff will issue a written decision in a
ratemaking proceeding whenever it or the Council disapproves an initial or past
rate for the basic service tier or associated equipment in whole or in part,
disapproves a request for a rate increase in whole or in part, or approves a
request for an increase in whole or in part over the objections of interested
parties. In the event that the Council has taken action which constitutes a
final decision of such nature, the written decision will not issue until
approved by Council. The Staff is not required to issue a written decision that
approves an unopposed past, existing or proposed rate for the basic service
tier or associated equipment. The written decision may follow the announcement
of a final decision by a period not to exceed thirty days, unless additional
time is necessary for Council approval as required in this section.
(Ord. 27-94. Passed 2-22-94.)
806.12 PROPRIETARY INFORMATION.
   Pursuant to 47 C.F.R. 76.938, the Staff may require the production of
proprietary information by the cable operator to make a rate determination and
in such cases the Staff will devise and apply procedures analogous to those set
forth in 47 C.F.R. 0.459 regarding requests for confidentiality. If no request
for confidentiality is made, or if the Staff denies a request for
confidentiality, the information will be made available for public inspection
pursuant to Ohio R.C. 149.43. A cable operator may appeal to the Council a
denial by the Staff of a request for confidentiality. The material which is
subject to the request for confidentiality will not be made available for
public inspection pending a Council decision on the request.
(Ord. 27-94. Passed 2-22-94.)
806.13 FORFEITURES FOR NONCOMPLIANCE.
   Pursuant to 47 C.F.R. 76.943(a), Council hereby authorizes the Mayor to
impose a civil monetary forfeiture on any cable operator that does not comply
with a rate decision or a refund order directed specifically at the cable
operator. In his or her decision to impose such a forfeiture, the Mayor may
consider the pendency of any appeals or legal action involving the rate
decision or refund order, the amount of the refund or rate reduction, and the
intentional or unintentional nature of the noncompliance. Such forfeitures may
be imposed pursuant to the following schedule:
   (a)   Failure to implement a rate reduction or refund within sixty days of
the date of the communication to the cable operator of the written decision
ordering such rate reduction or refund: $10,000.
   (b)   Failure to implement a rate reduction or refund after sixty days of
the date of the communication to the cable operator of the written decision
ordering such rate reduction or refund: $1,000 per day for each day of
noncompliance.
      (Ord. 27-94. Passed 2-22-94.)
806.14 BURDEN OF PROOF.
   (a)   Pursuant to 47 C.F.R. 76.937(a), a cable operator has the burden of
proving that its past, existing or proposed rates for basic service and
associated equipment comply with 47 U.S.C. 543 and 47 C.F.R. 76.922 and 76.923.
   (b)   For a past, existing or proposed rate for basic tier service or
associated equipment that is within the permitted tier charge and actual cost
of equipment, as set forth in 47 C.F.R. 76.922 and 76.923, the cable operator
must submit the appropriate FCC form.
   (c)   For a past, existing or proposed rate for basic tier service that
exceeds the permitted tier charge, as set forth in 47 C.F.R. 76.922 and 76.923,
the cable operator must submit a cost-of- service showing to justify the
proposed rate.
(Ord. 27-94. Passed 2-22-94.)
806.15 NOTIFICATION OF PROPOSED RATE INCREASE.
   Pursuant to 47 C.F.R. 76.932, a cable operator shall provide written notice
to a subscriber of any increase in the price to be charged for the basic
service tier or associated equipment at least thirty days before any proposed
increase is effective. The notice shall include the name and address of the
Council and the Staff.
(Ord. 27-94. Passed 2-22-94.)
806.16 CHANGE IN STATUS OF CABLE OPERATOR.
   (a)   Pursuant to 47 C.F.R. 76.915, a cable operator may petition the City
for a change in its regulatory status based on a showing of effective
competition. The operator bears the burden of proving the existence of
effective competition.
   (b)   Within a reasonable time of receiving a cable operator's petition for
a change in regulatory status, the Staff shall issue a public notice stating
that the City has received such a petition. The notice will contain a date for
the presentation of a recommended decision by the Staff to the Council. The
notice will also contain the address of the Staff office where the operator's
petition will be available for public viewing within specified times. The
notice will also provide the name and address of the cable operator. The cable
operator is required to provide interested parties with copies of the petition
upon request.
   (c)   Pursuant to 47 C.F.R. 76.915(a), oppositions to the operator's
petition may be filed with the Staff within fifteen days of public notice of
the filing of the petition, and must be served on the operator. The cable
operator may reply within seven days of filing of oppositions.
   (d)   The initial public notice issued by the Staff will contain a schedule
for the presentation of a recommended decision to the Council. Pursuant to 47
C.F.R. 76.915(b), decisions on petitions for change in status must be made
within thirty days after the pleading cycle set forth in subsections (b) and
(c) hereof closes. The Staff must notify the FCC within ten days of any
decision changing regulatory status. Unless the FCC receives an opposition to
such change in status, the decision will become effective thirty days after
adoption by the Council.
   (e)   Pursuant to 47 C.F.R. 76.915(c), if there is a final determination by
the Council that effective competition exists, then the Council and the Staff
will cease regulating basic cable service rates. A final determination that
there is no effective competition may be appealed to the FCC pursuant to the
FCC's rules.
(Ord. 27-94. Passed 2-22-94.)
CHAPTER 810
Deceptive Business Practices
810.01    Misrepresentation.
810.99    Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to regulate advertising- see Ohio R.C. 715.65
Business gifts of intoxicating liquor - see GEN. OFF.
612.12
Taking the identity of another - see GEN. OFF.
642.205
Receiving stolen property - see GEN. OFF.
642.22
 
 
810.01 MISREPRESENTATION.
   (a)   No person shall, in connection with any merchandise, securities,
service, employment, real estate or any other thing of value, offered by him
for use, purchase, lease, rental or sale, directly or indirectly make, publish,
disseminate, circulate or place before the public or any member thereof any
oral or written statement, announcement, advertisement, assertion,
representation, promise, affirmation or averment which is untrue or fraudulent,
in whole or in part, when he either knows or, in the exercise of reasonable
diligence, should have known of such falsity.
   (b)   No person shall knowingly cooperate in, cause or allow the commission
of any act constituting a violation of subsection (a) hereof.
   (c)   No person, knowing of an act committed by his employee or agent or by
any independent contractor hired by him, shall fail to take all reasonable
measures to correct any resulting false or misleading impression and to remedy
any damage resulting from a transaction induced in whole or in part by such
violation.
(W.V. Ord. 48-69. Passed 11-12-69.)
810.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates Section
810.01(a) or (b) shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more
than one thousand dollars ($1,000) or imprisoned not more than ten days, or
both. Whoever violates Section
810.01(c) shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than one
thousand dollars ($1,000).
(W.V. Ord. 48-69. Passed 11-12-69.)
CHAPTER 820
Game Rooms
820.01    Definitions.
820.02    Licenses required.
820.03    Issuance, display and effective period of licenses.
820.04   Periodic inspections.
820.05    Minors in game rooms; display of curfew laws.
820.06    Responsibilities of owners.
820.07    Gambling.
820.08    Suspension or revocation of licenses; appeals; Board of Review.
820.99    Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Gambling - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
624
Tampering with coin machines - see GEN. OFF.
642.13
Making or using slugs - see GEN. OFF.
642.16
Mechanical and electrical amusement devices - see
B.R. & T. Ch.
832 
 
 
820.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Game room" and "amusement arcade" mean a place of business within a
building or any part of a building having more than three mechanical or
electrical amusement devices which are used for the purpose of public
entertainment through the operation, use or play of any table game or device
commonly known as an electronic game which is operated by placing therein any
coin, plate, disc, plug, key or token of value or by the payment of a fee.
      (Ord. 75-81. Passed 12-28-81.)
   (b)   "Mechanical or electrical amusement device" means any coin-operated
machine, device or instrument which, upon the insertion of a coin, token or
slug, or upon payment of a fee, operates or may be operated for use as a game,
contest of skill or amusement, of any description, which in no way intends to
encourage gambling.
      (Ord. 63-82. Passed 9-13-82.)
   (c)   "Owner" means any person having possession of any mechanical or
electrical amusement device or any person operating an amusement arcade or a
game room.
      (Ord. 75-81. Passed 12-28-81.)
820.02 LICENSES REQUIRED.
   (a)   No person, being the owner of a game room or amusement arcade, shall
display for public patronage, or keep for operation by the public, any
mechanical or electrical amusement device without first obtaining a license
therefor, issued by the Safety Director or his or her designee, in accordance
with this chapter.
   (b)   Each owner of a game room or amusement arcade shall pay fifty dollars
($50.00) per year for an annual license for such game room or amusement arcade.
In addition, such owner shall also pay an annual license fee of twenty-five
dollars ($25.00) for each electrical or mechanical amusement device located in
such game room or amusement arcade, which devices shall be individually
registered by serial number.
   (c)   The licenses required by this section shall not be transferable to any
other person.
   (d)   No license shall be issued until an application therefor is submitted
to the Safety Director, or his or her designee, which application shall, among
other things, state:
      (1)   The name, address, age, birth date and social security number of
the applicant/owner;
      (2)   The location where the mechanical or electrical amusement device is
to be displayed or operated and the business conducted therein;
      (3)   A description of the machine to be covered by the license, its
mechanical or electrical features, the name of the manufacturer and the serial
number of such machine;
      (4)   The name of the owner of the premises wherein the device is to be
displayed or operated;
      (5)   The name of the owner of the business conducted therein; and
      (6)   Whether or not the applicant/owner of the machine has been
convicted of a gambling offense or a drug offense in the ten-year period
immediately preceding the date of the application.
         (Ord. 75-81. Passed 12-28-81.)
820.03 ISSUANCE, DISPLAY AND EFFECTIVE PERIOD OF LICENSES.
   (a)   If the applicant for a license has filed the proper application and
has paid the proper fee as specified in Section
820.02, and the Safety Director is satisfied that all information requested is
properly given, and that, after inspection by the Building Department, all
wiring and connections meet the then present Electrical Code standards, and
after a determination that sufficient parking spaces are in existence at the
subject property, i. e. at least one space for each mechanical or electrical
amusement device located therein, then a license shall be issued. In no event,
however, shall a license be issued for any such establishment unless it is
located in a commercially zoned area of the City or in an area allowing a
commercial establishment in accordance with the zoning laws of the City.
(Ord. 63-82. Passed 9-13-82.)
   (b)   The game room or amusement arcade license shall be displayed in a
prominent place in the business establishment. The license issued for each
mechanical or electrical amusement device shall be displayed on each such
device. The owner shall display such licenses during the period covered by such
licenses.
   (c)   For purposes of this chapter, all licenses shall terminate on December
31 of each calendar year and there shall be no prorating of fees. If any
licensed machine or device is replaced or substituted during the registration
period, a new application for such machine or device must be submitted with a
five dollar ($5.00) fee. The Safety Director shall then issue a new license on
such machine for the balance of the registration period.
(Ord. 75-81. Passed 12-28-81.)
820.04 PERIODIC INSPECTIONS.
   The owner of every game room or amusement arcade shall, at all times, permit
access by the Safety Director or his or her designee for the purpose of
periodically inspecting both the establishment and the mechanical or electrical
amusement devices.
(Ord. 75-81. Passed 12-28-81.)
820.05 MINORS IN GAME ROOMS; DISPLAY OF CURFEW LAWS.
   (a)   No person under the age of eighteen years shall be permitted to
operate a mechanical or electrical amusement device before 4:00 p.m. on school
days, unless accompanied by that person's parent or legal guardian. The owner
or operator of a game room or amusement arcade shall determine if, in fact,
school is in session for the individual playing or wishing to operate such a
device. On a day other than a school day, no minor under the age of eighteen
years shall operate such device prior to 9:00 a.m. No such device may be
operated by a minor under the age of sixteen years after 10:00 p.m., and after
12:00 midnight for a minor between sixteen and eighteen years of age, unless
accompanied by that person's parent or legal guardian.
   (b)   The owner shall prominently display in an area near the mechanical or
electrical amusement device, in his or her place of business, a clear legible
copy of the regulations governing the operation of the device by minors, and
the curfew laws of the City. Further, the owner or operator shall ascertain if
his or her patrons are violating such laws and, if so, eject them from the
establishment.
(Ord. 63-82. Passed 9-13-82.)
 
820.06 RESPONSIBILITIES OF OWNERS.
   (a)   No owner shall permit the consumption of intoxicants or alcoholic
beverages by any person on the premises.
   (b)   All game room and amusement arcade owners shall, during hours of
operation, provide adult (over the age of twenty-one years) management.
   (c)   The owner of any game room or amusement arcade shall provide necessary
security personnel to police the interior and exterior portion of the game room
or arcade as required by the Safety Director.
   (d)   All game room and amusement arcade owners shall submit to the Building
and Zoning Inspector an exterior lighting plan if such facility is in a free-
standing building or if required by the Safety Director, which plan shall be
approved by the Director.
   (e)   The owner shall maintain peace and quiet in and about the game room or
amusement arcade. Failure to do so shall constitute a nuisance and may be
grounds for revocation of licenses. For purposes of this section, a nuisance
shall be defined as any disturbance of the peace, as set forth in Section
648.05 of the General Offenses Code.
(Ord. 75-81. Passed 12-28-81.)
820.07 GAMBLING.
   (a)   The owner of any game room or amusement arcade shall prominently
display a sign indicating that gambling is prohibited. It shall further be
indicated on such sign that it shall be considered to be a gambling offense if
a player agrees to pay for the game of another upon the loss of a game.
   (b)   No mechanical or electrical amusement device shall be permitted that
has as its object the skill of winning at the playing of cards, dice, craps or
roulette.
(Ord. 75-81. Passed 12-28-81.)
820.08 SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSES; APPEALS; BOARD OF REVIEW.
   The Safety Director may suspend or revoke any license issued pursuant to
this chapter for a direct or indirect violation of any of the provisions of
this chapter. If the Director suspends or revokes a license, the owner may,
within ten days, appeal such suspension or revocation to the Mayor. If the
Mayor upholds such suspension or revocation, the owner may appeal to a Board of
Review within ten days from the Mayor's decision, such Board to consist of one
member of Council and the Director of Law. The decision of the Board shall be
final.
(Ord. 75-81. Passed 12-28-81.)
820.99 PENALTY.
   In addition to the suspension or revocation of a license under Section
820.08, whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a
misdemeanor of the third degree and shall be fined not more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned not more than sixty days, or both, for each
offense.
(Ord. 75-81. Passed 12-28-81.)
CHAPTER 824
Home Purchase and Construction Contractors
824.01    Definitions.
824.02    False affidavits and material facts.
824.99    Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Theft by deception - see GEN. OFF.
642.02(a)(3)
Building Code - see B. & H. Ch.
1420 et seq.
Condominiums - see B. & H. Ch.
1479
Housing Code - see B. & H. Ch.
1480
 
 
824.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Home construction contract" means a contract entered into between an
original contractor and an owner, part owner or lessee for:
      (1)   The building, construction, repair, replacement, remodeling,
alteration, conversion, modernization or improvement of any single or two-
family dwelling, or portion of the dwelling, or a residential unit of a
condominium property that has been subjected to the provisions of Ohio R. C.
Chapter 5311;
      (2)   An addition to any land; or
      (3)   The construction, replacement, installation or improvement of
driveways, sidewalks, swimming pools, porches, garages, carports, landscaping,
fences, fallout shelters, siding, roofing, storm windows and awnings and other
improvements that are adjacent to single or two-family dwellings or on lands
that are adjacent to single or two-family dwellings or residential units of a
condominium property, if the dwelling, residential unit of condominium property
or land is used or intended to be used as a personal residence by the owner,
part owner or lessee.
   (b)   "Home purchase contract" means a contract for the purchase of any
single or two- family dwelling or residential unit of a condominium property
that has been subjected to the provisions of Ohio R. C. Chapter 5311, if the
purchaser uses or intends to use the dwelling, a unit of a two-family dwelling
or the condominium unit as his or her personal residence.
   (c)   "Lending institution" means a person who enters into a contract with
the owner, part owner, purchaser or lessee to provide financing for a home
construction contract or a home purchase contract, which financing is secured
in whole or in part by a mortgage on the real estate on which the improvements
contemplated by the home construction contract are to be made or on the
property that is the subject of the home purchase contract, and who or which
makes direct disbursements under the contract to any original contractor or the
owner, part owner, purchaser or lessee.
   (d)   "Original contractor" means a person with whom the owner, part owner,
lessee or purchaser under a home purchase contract has directly contracted.
      (Ord. 78-15. Passed 3-14-78.)
824.02 FALSE AFFIDAVITS AND MATERIAL FACTS.
   No original contractor shall:
   (a)   Knowingly supply a false affidavit to a lending institution, owner,
part owner or lessee for the purpose of obtaining payment under a home
construction contract or home purchase contract; or
   (b)   Obtain payment from a lending institution, owner, part owner or lessee
under a home purchase contract or for work done pursuant to a home construction
contract when the contractor is aware that such payment is based on the
assumption of a material fact which the payer considers to be true and which
the contractor knows or should know is false, or when the contractor has made,
either directly or indirectly to the payer, a statement of material fact which
is false, under circumstances in which the contractor knew or should have known
that such statement was false, or when the contractor makes the statement
without knowing whether it is true or false. For the purposes of this
subsection, a material fact is one on which a reasonable man would form a
decision as to whether to make or withhold payment.
      (Ord. 78-15. Passed 3-14-78.)
824.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a
misdemeanor of the second degree and shall be fined not more than seven hundred
fifty dollars ($750.00) or imprisoned not more than ninety days, or both, for
each offense.
(Ord. 78-15. Passed 3-14-78.)
CHAPTER 832
Mechanical and Electrical Amusement Devices
832.01    Definitions.
832.02    License required.
832.03    Issuance, display and effective period of license.
832.04    Periodic inspections.
832.05    Operation by minors; display of curfew laws.
832.06    Peace disturbances as nuisances.
832.07    Gambling.
832.08    Suspension or revocation of licenses; appeals; Board of Review.
832.99    Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Gambling - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
624
Tampering with coin machines - see GEN. OFF.
642.13
Making or using slugs - see GEN. OFF.
642.16
Game rooms - see B.R. & T. Ch.
820
 
 
832.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Mechanical or electrical amusement device" means any coin-operated
machine, device or instrument, which, upon the insertion of a coin, token or
slug, or upon payment of a fee, operates or may be operated for use as a game,
contest of skill or amusement, of any description, which in no way intends to
encourage gambling.
   (b)   "Owner" means any person having possession of any mechanical or
electrical amusement device or any person operating any such device, other than
the owner or operator of a game room as defined in Section
820.01(a).
      (Ord. 61-82. Passed 9-13-82.)
832.02 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (a)   No person shall display for public patronage, or keep for operation by
the public, any mechanical or electrical amusement device without first
obtaining a license therefor, issued by the Safety Director or his or her
designee, in accordance with this chapter.
   (b)   The owner shall pay an annual license fee of twenty-five dollars
($25.00) for each electrical or mechanical amusement device, which shall be
individually registered by serial number.
   (c)   The licenses required by this section shall not be transferable to any
other person.
   (d)   No license shall be issued until an application is submitted to the
Director or his or her designee, which application shall, among other things,
state:
      (1)   The name, address, age, birth date and social security number of
the applicant/owner;
      (2)   The location where the mechanical or electrical amusement device is
to be displayed or operated and the business conducted therein;
      (3)   A description of the machine to be covered by the license, its
mechanical or electrical features, the name of the manufacturer and the serial
number of such machine;
      (4)   The name of the owner of the premises wherein the device is to be
displayed or operated;
      (5)   The name of the owner of the business conducted therein; and
      (6)   Whether or not the applicant/owner of the machine has been
convicted of a gambling offense or a drug offense in the ten-year period
immediately preceding the date of the application.
         (Ord. 61-82. Passed 9-13-82.)
832.03 ISSUANCE, DISPLAY AND EFFECTIVE PERIOD OF LICENSE.
   (a)   If the applicant for a license has filed the proper application and
has paid the proper fee as specified in Section
832.02(b), and the Safety Director is satisfied that all information requested
is properly given, and that, after inspection by the Building Department, that
all wiring and connections meet the then present Electrical Code standards,
then a license shall be issued. In no event, however, shall a license be issued
for any such establishment unless it is located in a commercially zoned area of
the City or in an area allowing a commercial establishment in accordance with
the zoning laws of the City.
   (b)   The license issued for each mechanical or electrical amusement device
shall be displayed on each such device. The owner shall display such license
during the period covered by such license.
   (c)   For purposes of this chapter, all licenses shall terminate on December
31 of each calendar year and there shall be no prorating of fees. If any
licensed machine or device is replaced or substituted during the registration
period, a new application for such machine or device must be submitted with a
five dollar ($5.00) fee. The Director shall then issue a new license on such
machine for the balance of the registration period.
(Ord. 61-82. Passed 9-13-82.)
832.04 PERIODIC INSPECTIONS.
   The owner of a mechanical or electrical amusement device shall, at all
times, permit access by the Safety Director or his or her designee for the
purpose of periodically inspecting both the establishment and the mechanical or
electrical amusement device.
(Ord. 61-82. Passed 9-13-82.)
832.05 OPERATION BY MINORS; DISPLAY OF CURFEW LAWS.
   (a)   No person under the age of eighteen years shall be permitted to
operate a mechanical or electrical amusement device before 4:00 p.m. on school
days, unless accompanied by that person's parent or legal guardian. The owner
or operator of each device shall determine if, in fact, school is in session
for the individual playing or wishing to operate such device. On a day, other
than a school day, no minor under the age of eighteen years shall operate such
device prior to 9:00 a.m. No such device may be operated by a minor under the
age of sixteen years after 10:00 p.m., and after 12:00 midnight for minors
between sixteen and eighteen years of age, unless accompanied by that person's
parent or legal guardian.
   (b)   The owner shall prominently display in an area near the mechanical or
electrical amusement device, in his or her place of business, a clear legible
copy of the regulations governing the operation of the device by minors, and
the curfew laws of the City. Further, the owner or operator shall ascertain if
his or her patrons are violating such laws and, if so, eject them from the
establishment.
(Ord. 61-82. Passed 9-13-82.)
832.06 PEACE DISTURBANCES AS NUISANCES.
   The owner shall maintain peace and quiet in and about the premises and
location of any mechanical or electrical amusement device. Failure to do so
shall constitute a nuisance and may be grounds for revocation of licenses. For
purposes of this section, a nuisance shall be defined as any disturbance of the
peace, as set forth in Section
648.05 of the General Offenses Code.
(Ord. 61-82. Passed 9-13-82.)
832.07 GAMBLING.
   (a)   The owner of any mechanical or electrical amusement device shall
prominently display a sign indicating that gambling is prohibited. It shall
further be indicated on such sign that it shall be considered to be a gambling
offense if a player agrees to pay for the game of another upon the loss of a
game.
   (b)   No mechanical or electrical amusement device shall be permitted that
has as its object the skill of winning at the playing of cards, dice, craps or
roulette.
(Ord. 61-82. Passed 9-13-82.)
832.08 SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSES; APPEALS; BOARD OF REVIEW.
   The Safety Director may suspend or revoke any license issued pursuant to
this chapter for a direct or indirect violation of any of the provisions of
this chapter. If the Director suspends or revokes any license, the owner may,
within ten days, appeal such suspension or revocation to the Mayor. If the
Mayor upholds such suspension or revocation, the owner may appeal to a Board of
Review within ten days from the Mayor's decision, such Board to consist of one
member of Council and the Director of Law. The decision of the Board shall be
final.
(Ord. 61-82. Passed 9-13-82.)
832.99 PENALTY.
   In addition to the suspension or revocation of a license under Section
832.08, whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a
misdemeanor of the third degree and shall be fined not more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned not more than sixty days, or both, for each
offense.
(Ord. 61-82. Passed 9-13-82.)
CHAPTER 836
Oil and Gas Wells
   EDITOR'S NOTE: Chapter
836, previously a codification of Ordinance 106-80, passed December 22, 1980,
Ordinance 13-81, passed February 23, 1981, and new matter, was repealed and re-
enacted in its entirety by Ordinance 29-83, passed March 29, 1983.
836.01    Definitions.
836.02    Drilling; permit required; fee.
836.03    Permit application.
836.04    Investigation by Building, Housing and Zoning Administrator;
rejection of permit; appeals.
836.05    Conditions of permit.
836.06    Termination of permit.
836.07    Limitations on location.
836.08    Modification of existing wells; removal of debris.
836.09    Abandoning or plugging; permit required; fee.
836.10    Manner of plugging.
836.11    Precautions regarding abandoned wells.
836.12    Hours and manner of operation.
836.13    Salt water and oil field waste; storage pits; disposal.
836.14    Concealing equipment by landscaping; fencing.
836.15    Maintenance of equipment.
836.16    Fire safety standards.
836.17   Notification of hazards.
836.18    Weekly inspections.
836.99    Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Oil and gas wells - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 1509
Leasing of natural gas and oil lands - see Ohio R.C. 5301.09
 
 
836.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Abandoned well" means any producing well that has not been operated
for six months and any drilling operation that has ceased for thirty
consecutive days.
   (b)   "City" means the City of Olmsted Falls.
   (c)   "Deleterious matter" means any chemical, salt water, oil field brine,
waste oil, waste emulsified oil, basic sediment, mud or injurious substance
produced or used in the drilling, development, producing, transportation,
refining and processing of oil or gas.
   (d)   "Permittee" means the person to whom a permit is issued.
   (e)   "Person" means and includes any person, firm, partnership,
association, corporation, trust, cooperative or other type of organization.
   (f)   "Pollution" means the contamination or other alteration of the
physical, chemical or biological properties of any natural water of the City,
or such a discharge of any liquid, gaseous or solid substance into any water of
the City as will, or is likely to, create a nuisance or render such water
harmful, detrimental or injurious to the public health, safety or welfare; to
domestic, commercial, industrial, agricultural, recreational or other
beneficial uses; or to livestock, animals or aquatic life.
   (g)   "Water" or "waters of the City" means all streams, ditches, lakes,
ponds, marshes, watercourses, waterways, wells, springs, drainage systems and
all other bodies or accumulations of water, surface and underground, natural or
artificial, public or private, which are contained within, flow through or
border upon the City or any portion thereof.
   (h)   "Well" means any hole or bore, to any depth, for the purpose of
producing and recovering any oil and gas.
      (Ord. 29-83. Passed 3-29-83.)
836.02 DRILLING; PERMIT REQUIRED; FEE.
   No person shall drill a gas or oil well in the City without first obtaining
a permit therefor from the Building, Housing and Zoning Administrator. The fee
for such a permit is one hundred dollars ($100.00).
(Ord. 29-83. Passed 3-29-83.)
836.03 PERMIT APPLICATION.
   (a)   Every application to drill an original well or to re-enter an
abandoned well shall be in writing, signed by the applicant or by some person
duly authorized to sign the same on his or her behalf, and accompanied by the
permit fee. No application shall request a permit to drill more than one well.
The application shall include the following:
      (1)   The name and address of the applicant;
      (2)   A block map of the twenty acres surrounding the drill site,
including the location of the proposed well, distances therefrom to all
existing dwelling houses, buildings or other structures designed for the
occupancy of human beings or animals within 500 feet of any such well, and the
location of all waters of the City and existing oil, gas or fresh water wells
within the twenty-acre tract;
      (3)   A copy of the State drilling permit;
      (4)   A statement of the proposed drilling schedule, listing when the
drilling is expected to begin and to be completed, when the driveway is to be
installed, a tentative schedule for the removal of all litter, machinery and
deleterious matter accumulated in the drilling operation, and plans showing
fencing and landscaping around wells and tanks, with a proposed schedule for
completion;
      (5)   The name or names of those persons directly responsible for the
drilling operation and maintenance of the well, listing telephone numbers and
addresses where such individuals may be contacted if an emergency arises;
      (6)   A sworn statement that the owner has in force and will maintain,
until abandonment of his or her oil or gas well in the City, liability
insurance listing the City as an additional insured, in an amount of not less
than three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000) bodily injury coverage and one
hundred thousand dollars ($100,000) property damage coverage, to pay damages
for injury to persons or damage to property caused by the drilling, operation
or plugging of each well; and
      (7)   A copy of a restoration plan for the restoration of land surfaces,
as required by Ohio R.C. 1509.06(M), and, where applicable, a land owner waiver
form.
   (b)   Where the application is one for re-entry of an abandoned well, such
application shall contain all the information set forth in subsection (a)
hereof, and shall provide the following:
      (1)   A statement of the condition of the well; and
      (2)   Evidence of adequate current tests showing that the casing strings
currently passed the same tests that are required in the case of the drilling
of an original well.
   (c)   A copy of a spill prevention control and countermeasure plan shall be
filed with the City for storage facilities having a capacity of 1,320 gallons
of oil or single containers in excess of 660 gallons.
(Ord. 29-83. Passed 3-29-83.)
836.04 INVESTIGATION BY BUILDING, HOUSING AND ZONING ADMINISTRATOR; REJECTION
OF PERMIT; APPEALS.
   (a)   The Building, Housing and Zoning Administrator, upon receipt of a plot
plan and an application for a permit to drill a gas or oil well, will cause an
investigation to be made of the premises for which such permit is sought. Upon
completion of the investigation, the Administrator shall submit a report of
such investigation, with the application for the permit and the plot plan, to
the Planning Commission for its recommendation. The Commission may recommend
approval or disapproval of the application, depending upon compliance or
noncompliance thereon with this chapter.
   (b)   The Commission may recommend rejection of any application for a permit
where, by reason of the location of the proposed well and the character and
value of the permanent improvements already erected, and the use to which the
land and surrounding areas are adapted for civic purposes, or for sanitary
reasons, the drilling of an oil or gas well will constitute a threat to the
health, safety or welfare of the City or its residents. When a permit is
refused, the deposit of cash required to be made with the application shall be
returned to the applicant. Appeals from the denial of a permit shall be to the
Board of Zoning Appeals as provided by the City Charter and these Codified
Ordinances.
   (c)   The Commission shall review and approve plans for fencing and
landscaping of the site in accordance with Section
836.14.
(Ord. 29-83. Passed 3-29-83.)
836.05 CONDITIONS OF PERMIT.
   The Building, Housing and Zoning Administrator shall issue a permit to drill
a gas or oil well, or to install tanks, upon receipt of the application and
after a review by the Planning Commission, which permit shall be conditioned on
the following:
   (a)   The applicant shall furnish a surety bond in the sum of two hundred
thousand dollars ($200,000), approved by the Law Director, ensuring the
faithful performance of all the laws, rules and regulations of the City, and
further ensuring protection to the City for any damage occurring to the City or
to public property. The bond shall be in force and effect during the entire
operation of the drilling, until such time as the well is capped and for thirty
days thereafter, at which time the applicant may discontinue the bond if he or
she has complied with all conditions thereof. If the applicant chooses to
discontinue his or her bond, as herein provided, he or she must deposit with
the Administrator his or her insurance policies for property damage and
personal injury as specified in Section
836.03(a)(6). Such policies shall not only protect the City as an additional
insured for property damage or injury to third persons, but must also protect
the City for damage to City property or injury to City employees.
   (b)   Prior to any drilling operation, a suitable driveway of 100 feet in
length and capable of supporting fire equipment shall be installed and
maintained as such during the operating life of the well or tank site. When the
driveway crosses an open roadway ditch, a culvert pipe, approved by the
Administrator as to size, material and location, shall be installed to ensure
proper drainage. The spreading of mud and debris upon City streets is
prohibited and the driller shall clean any mud or debris from the streets to
the satisfaction oi the Administrator, the Service Director or the Safety
Director. If it is not completed to the satisfaction of the appropriate
authority, the City shall clean the area and all charges shall be paid by the
permittee.
   (c)   The applicant shall faithfully observe all provisions of law relating
to drilling a gas or oil well.
   (d)   The applicant shall restore all streets, sidewalks, utilities, public
grounds and private grounds, and all places in the City which may be damaged,
to their former condition.
   (e)   The applicant shall clear the area of all litter, machinery, derricks,
buildings, oil or other substances accumulated in the drilling operation.
   (f)   The applicant shall pay any and all damages for property damage or
personal injury arising out of the drilling operation.
   (g)   Fresh water wells located within a radius of one-fourth of a mile
(1,320 feet) of any well shall be tested prior to drilling. Residents may waive
this requirement. Such testing is the responsibility of the permittee, shall be
at the permittee's expense and shall be conducted by a person approved by the
City. Test results shall be filed with the City. If any fresh water well
located within a radius of one-fourth of a mile is disturbed or altered, a new
test will be taken for the presence of deleterious materials, such as
chlorides, sulphates, hydrocarbons and dissolved solids, etc. Such testing is
the responsibility of the permittee, shall be at the permittee's expense and
shall be conducted by a person approved by the City. Test results shall be
filed with the City. If the test shows the fresh water well was not altered by
the well or tanks, the cost of the testing will be paid by the complainant.
         If the fresh water well is proven to have been disturbed by the well
or tanks, the permittee shall immediately correct the problem. Potable water,
in amounts needed by the well user, shall be provided by the permittee, and a
new fresh water well shall be drilled immediately to ensure an adequate potable
fresh water supply to those injured parties. If a new fresh water well is not
drilled within thirty days, the permittee shall suspend his or her operation
and be fined one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day until a new fresh water well
is drilled. The fine shall be in addition to any other penalty provided in this
chapter.
   (h)   No permit shall be issued for the drilling of a well except upon the
ground owned by the applicant, or upon the ground held by the applicant under
an oil and gas lease or drilling contract from the owner, giving permission to
drill the well. Nothing contained in this chapter, nor any permit issued
pursuant to this chapter, shall be deemed to grant any right or license to the
permittee to enter upon or occupy, in any respect, for drilling or production
operations, any land, except by written permission of the owner thereof. Any
permittee entering upon or occupying, in any respect, for drilling or
production operations, any land, without the written permission of the owner
thereof, shall be charged under Section
642.12 (Criminal Trespass) of the General Offenses Code.
      (Ord. 29-83. Passed 3-29-83.)
836.06 TERMINATION OF PERMIT.
   When a permit is issued pursuant to this chapter, the same shall terminate
and become inoperative, without any action on the part of the City, unless,
within six months from the date of issuance, actual drilling of the well has
commenced. The cessation of the drilling operation for six months shall operate
to terminate and cancel the permit, and the well shall be deemed abandoned.
Thereafter, no person shall drill or operate any such well within the City
without the issuance of another permit.
(Ord. 29-83. Passed 3-29-83.)
836.07 LIMITATIONS ON LOCATION.
   No person shall act or use any drilling rig or storage tank, or build any
related structure, nearer than 500 feet from any inhabited private dwelling
house, without first obtaining written consent from the private property owner;
or nearer than 500 feet from any public building which may be used as a place
of resort, assembly, education, entertainment, lodging, trade, manufacture,
repair, storage, traffic or occupancy by the public, without first obtaining,
in writing, the consent of all the owners of public buildings within that
radius as measured from the center of the proposed well. No person shall act or
use any drilling rig or storage tank nearer than 500 feet from any private
water supply, or nearer than 500 feet from any other gas or oil well. However,
where a unique or unusual condition exists, and undue hardship will result by
compliance with these requirements, Council may, at its discretion, amend the
distance requirements.
(Ord. 29-83. Passed 3-29-83.)
836.08 MODIFICATION OF EXISTING WELLS; REMOVAL OF DEBRIS.
   (a)   No person shall extend, deepen or enlarge any existing gas or oil well
without first obtaining a permit therefor from the Building, Housing and Zoning
Administrator. Application for such a permit shall be made to the Administrator
upon such forms as he or she may prescribe, and such application shall be
accompanied by a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). A separate application shall be
filed for each well to be extended, deepened or enlarged.
   (b)   No person shall use, erect or construct any drilling rig or storage
tank within 500 feet of any private dwelling house or public building, for the
purpose of extending or deepening any existing gas or oil well, without first
obtaining written permission therefor from the owner of such dwelling or
building.
   (c)   No person shall extend, deepen or enlarge any existing gas or oil well
or erect any storage tank within 100 feet of the nearest point of a dedicated
portion of any street, highway or railroad right of way.
   (d)   A permit is not required in order to swab, bail or remove debris from
any existing gas or oil well.
(Ord. 29-83. Passed 3-29-83.)
836.09 ABANDONING OR PLUGGING; PERMIT REQUIRED; FEE.
   (a)   No person shall abandon or cause to be abandoned a gas or oil well
without first obtaining a permit therefor from the Building, Housing and Zoning
Administrator. The fee for such a permit is five dollars ($5.00).
   (b)   No person shall cause a gas or oil well to be abandoned or plugged
without first notifying the Administrator and the Fire Chief of the intent to
abandon or plug such well. Such person, after notification, shall furnish to
the Administrator a plot plan by a licensed surveyor indicating thereon the
exact location of the well to be abandoned or plugged. Upon compliance with the
notification and plot plan requirements set forth herein, the application for a
permit to abandon or plug may be obtained from the Administrator.
(Ord. 29-83. Passed 3-29-83.)
836.10 MANNER OF PLUGGING.
   All abandoned gas or oil wells must be plugged in the manner prescribed by
the Ohio Division of Mines, the laws of the State and this chapter, and shall
be done under the supervision of the Building, Housing and Zoning Administrator
and a representative of the Division.
(Ord. 29-83. Passed 3-29-83.)
836.11 PRECAUTIONS REGARDING ABANDONED WELLS.
   (a)   Any person, being the owner or lessee of land, who discovers an
abandoned gas or oil well, shall immediately notify the Fire Department and/or
the Building, Housing and Zoning Administrator.
   (b)   Any person who discovers an abandoned gas or oil well during the
development of any land or during the construction of any building shall
immediately cease all operations until notification is given to the
Administrator and the Fire Chief and until such well is treated in accordance
with this chapter.
   (c)   No person engaged in any phase of construction shall remove any casing
or piping of any abandoned well until such well has been reported to the
Inspector and the Chief and the representative of the Ohio Division of Mines.
No construction shall take place either over or near an abandoned gas or oil
well until such well has been made, by the Chief, to conform with the laws of
the State and this chapter.
(Ord. 29-83. Passed 3-29-83.)
836.12 HOURS AND MANNER OF OPERATION.
   Drilling is permitted twenty-four hours a day, but no driller shall detonate
explosive devices, perform the process called fracturing, dress tools, sharpen
bits or operate his or her forge between 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. of the next
day in any area where there are inhabited dwellings within 500 feet of any
drilling operation, unless the consent of all property owners within such
distance is obtained. All operations shall be conducted in such a manner as to
eliminate, as far as practical, dust, noise, vibration and noxious odors.
(Ord. 29-83. Passed 3-29-83.)
836.13 SALT WATER AND OIL FIELD WASTE; STORAGE PITS; DISPOSAL.
   All pits used for the temporary storage of salt water and oil field waste
shall be lined to be liquid-tight and constructed and maintained so as to
prevent the escape of salt water and oil field waste. The level of salt and oil
field waste in excavated pits shall, at no time, be permitted to rise above the
lowest point of the ground surface level. Salt water and oil field waste shall
be removed by tanker and transported to a proper disposal area periodically, at
intervals not to exceed sixty days. Salt water and oil field waste shall not be
disposed of by draining the same into an open field, open ditch, storm sewer or
running stream.
(Ord. 29-83. Passed 3-29-83.)
836.14 CONCEALING EQUIPMENT BY LANDSCAPING; FENCING.
   All storage tanks and other equipment remaining at the well site after
drilling operations are complete shall be fenced with a locked gate within
thirty days. The Planning Commission shall determine if landscaping, i. e.
trees, bushes, fences, etc., around equipment and tanks, is required to provide
concealment for abutting properties and surrounding properties, and such
landscaping plan shall be submitted to the Commission for approval. The
landscaping shall be maintained in good condition. All dead and dying
landscaping shall be removed and replaced.
(Ord. 29-83. Passed 3-29-83.)
836.15 MAINTENANCE OF EQUIPMENT.
   All equipment shall be painted and remain in a good state of appearance. No
person shall permit a gas or oil well or tank to become deteriorated, damaged
or in such disrepair as to cause leakage of gas or oil. Such leakage of gas or
oil shall constitute a nuisance and repairs shall be made immediately.
(Ord. 29-83. Passed 3-29-83.)
836.16 FIRE SAFETY STANDARDS.
   (a)   The permittee shall have a "danger" sign, as approved by the Fire
Department, posted at all sites. Such sign shall list the permittee's name and
emergency number.
   (b)   All high voltage electrical boxes shall be locked.
   (c)   Persons drilling shall take all precautions necessary to minimize fire
hazards and the possibility of fire. Extinguishers of at least 20# CO2 or ABC
shall be readily available when initial drilling is being done.
(Ord. 29-83. Passed 3-29-83.)
836.17 NOTIFICATION OF HAZARDS.
   The permittee shall notify the City of any spills, leaks, explosions, fires
or potential hazards immediately through the dispatcher at 235-1212 or 235-
1234. A written report shall be filed with the City within thirty days,
describing the problem, the reason for the same and the solution, and stating
whether or not any long term effects are anticipated.
   If, in the judgment of the Building, Housing and Zoning Administrator or the
Fire Department, a hazard to life or property or a fire hazard exists, he or
she or it may order the cause to be immediately corrected. If no action is
taken, the site will be closed down.
(Ord. 29-83. Passed 3-29-83.)
836.18 WEEKLY INSPECTIONS.
   The Building, Housing and Zoning Administrator shall inspect all sites
weekly and shall maintain a log on file for each site.
(Ord. 29-83. Passed 3-29-83.)
836.99 PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter, for which no penalty is otherwise provided, shall be fined not more
than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned not more than six months, or
both. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on which
a violation or noncompliance occurs or continues.
   (b)   Whoever violates or fails to comply with Section
836.17 shall be fined one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense. A
separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on which a
violation or noncompliance occurs or continues.
(Ord. 29-83. Passed 3-29-83.)
CHAPTER 840
Peddlers and Solicitors
EDITOR'S NOTE: Chapter
840, previously a codification of Ordinance 2-77, passed February 22, 1977, and
new matter, was repealed and re-enacted in its entirety by Ordinance 62-82,
passed July 29, 1982.
840.01    Definitions.
840.02    Uninvited peddling and soliciting.
840.03    Exemptions.
840.99    Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.61 et seq.
Home solicitation sales - see Ohio R.C. 1345.21
Charitable solicitations - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 1716
Frozen desserts - see Ohio R.C. 3717.51 et seq.
Trespassing - see GEN. OFF.
642.12
Sales from public ways - see B. R. & T. Ch.
850
 
 
840.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter, "solicitor," "canvasser," "peddler" and "hawker"
mean any person, whether a resident of the City or not, who sells or offers for
sale within the City, any goods or chattels of any kind, by going from house to
house or from place to place through the streets of the City with such goods or
chattels on his or her person or in his or her possession or under his or her
control, or who sells by subscription or by taking orders for future delivery
of goods or chattels of any kind, whether such person travels by foot, wagon,
motor vehicle or any other type of conveyance.
(Ord. 62-82. Passed 7-29-82.)
840.02 UNINVITED PEDDLING AND SOLICITING.
   The practice of going in and upon private residences of the City by
solicitors, peddlers, hawkers, itinerant merchants or transient vendors of
merchandise or services, not having been requested or invited to do so by the
owner or occupant of such private residence, for the purpose of soliciting
orders for the sale of goods, chattels, wares, merchandise or services, and/or
disposing of and/or peddling or hawking the same, is hereby declared to be a
nuisance and is prohibited.
(Ord. 62-82. Passed 7-29-82.)
840.03 EXEMPTIONS.
   (a)   Sections
840.01 and
840.02 shall not apply to the following classes of persons who shall be
permitted to solicit between 9:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. persons who solicit of
religious, educational, charitable or civic organizations listed as exempt from
payment of Federal income taxes by the Internal Revenue Service; newspaper
carriers; commercial travelers or sales agents calling on commercial
establishments; persons engaged in the sale of dairy and bakery products by
traveling over regularly established routes and transacting business on private
property; ice cream trucks traveling random routes throughout the City; and
persons engaged in the delivery of dry cleaned articles over a regularly
established route and doing so on private property.
   (b)   Any such person set forth in subsection (a) hereof shall be subject to
proof of his or her qualification of his or her status, as set forth in
subsection (a) hereof, upon request by a police officer of the City.
(Ord. 1-92. Passed 2-11-92; Ord. 38-2021. Passed 6-22-21.)  
840.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or
imprisoned not more than thirty days, or both, for each offense. A separate
offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on which a violation or
noncompliance occurs or continues.
(Ord. 62-82. Passed 7-29-82.)
CHAPTER 850
Sales From Public Ways

850.01 CONGESTION OF TRAFFIC.
   No person shall exhibit, demonstrate, offer for sale or barter or sell or
barter any piece of tangible personal property upon or from any public sidewalk
in the City or on any portion of his private property adjoining such public
sidewalk if such use of private property causes, tends to cause, encourages or
increases congestion of traffic on such sidewalk or on an adjacent public way.
(W.V. Ord. 1968-40. Passed 9-24-68.)
850.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not
more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). A separate offense shall be deemed
committed each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues.
CHAPTER 860
Sexually-Oriented Businesses
